title: HPM 883: Advanced Quantitative Methods
text:
HPM 883 is an advanced graduate-level course designed to equip PhD students in Health Policy and Management with sophisticated quantitative research skills. This course is the third installment in the quantitative methods sequence, building on foundations from HPM 881 and HPM 882.
Focus Areas:

Experimental design and randomization inference
Double/Debiased Machine Learning (DML)
Heterogeneous treatment effects and causal forests
Policy learning and optimal treatment rules
Modern causal inference methods (DiD, synthetic controls)






Instructor
Sean Sylvia


Meeting Time
Mon/Wed 11:15am - 12:30pm


Location
Rosenau 228 / Zoom (hybrid)


Office Hours
Wed 2:00-4:00pm


Credits
3

title: Computing
text:
HPM 883 uses a three-tier computing environment designed to minimize setup friction while teaching reproducible research workflows.






TipQuick Links




Student Setup Guide — Complete installation instructions
Lab 0: Environment Verification — Verify your setup works
Troubleshooting — Common problems and solutions









Tier
Platform
When to Use
Cost




In-Class
Posit Cloud
Lectures, code-alongs, live demos
$5/month


Projects
Local (Positron) + GitHub
Labs, capstone, independent work
Free


Submission
GitHub Classroom
All graded assignments
Free





For in-class exercises, we use Posit Cloud — a browser-based R environment with zero setup.
Benefits:

Works on any computer with a browser
Pre-configured with all required packages
Instructor can see your work in real-time

Cost: $5/month (Student plan) — Sign up here
How it works:

Log into Posit Cloud
Join the HPM 883 course workspace (link provided in class)
Open the assignment project
Code along with the instructor




For labs and the capstone project, you’ll work locally using Positron (recommended) or RStudio.
Why local development?

Faster performance
Built-in AI assistance (Positron)
Learn real-world reproducible workflow
Works offline

Template Repositories:



Template
Purpose
Link




Lab Template
Weekly lab assignments
hpm883-lab-template


Capstone Template
Semester project
hpm883-capstone-template






All graded work is submitted via GitHub Classroom.
Workflow:

Click the assignment link (provided on course website)
Accept the assignment → creates your personal repo
Clone to your computer
Complete the work
Commit and push to GitHub
GitHub Classroom records your submission time








R is our primary analysis language.
Windows:
winget install --id R-project.R
macOS:
brew install --cask r



Positron is Posit’s new IDE with built-in AI assistance.



Feature
Positron
RStudio




Built-in AI assistant
✓
✗


Active development
✓
Maintenance only


VS Code extensions
✓
Limited


Price
Free
Free



Download: positron.posit.co
Alternative: RStudio Desktop if you prefer.



Version control for all assignments.
Windows:
winget install Git.Git
macOS:
brew install git
Configure:
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your.email@unc.edu"



Publishing system for labs and reports. Usually bundled with Positron/RStudio.
Verify installation:
quarto --version
If not installed: quarto.org/docs/get-started







Platform: Posit Cloud

Log into Posit Cloud
Open the class project
Follow along with instructor
No submission needed




Platform: Local + GitHub Classroom

Accept assignment via GitHub Classroom link
Clone to local machine:

git clone git@github.com:unc-hpm-quant/lab-X-yourusername.git

Open .Rproj file in Positron/RStudio
Restore packages: renv::restore()
Complete the lab in analysis.qmd
Render to HTML
Commit and push:

git add .
git commit -m "Complete Lab X"
git push



Platform: Local + GitHub Classroom
Same workflow as labs, but uses the capstone template with:

_targets.R — Analysis pipeline
analysis/01-pap.qmd — Pre-analysis plan
analysis/02-analysis.qmd — Main analysis
analysis/03-results.qmd — Results summary






These packages are pre-installed in all course templates:





Package
Purpose




tidyverse
Data manipulation and visualization


estimatr
Robust standard errors


gt
Publication-quality tables


knitr
Document rendering









Package
Purpose




DoubleML
Double/Debiased Machine Learning


grf
Generalized Random Forests (causal forests)


policytree
Policy learning and decision trees


did
Difference-in-Differences


Synth
Synthetic Control Method









Package
Purpose




DeclareDesign
Research design declaration


fabricatr
Data simulation


randomizr
Randomization








All course projects use renv for package management.
First time opening a project:
renv::restore()
This installs the exact package versions used to create the project.
If you add new packages:
install.packages("new_package")
renv::snapshot()






# Delete cached packages and retry
unlink("renv/library", recursive = TRUE)
renv::restore()



# Pull remote changes first
git pull --rebase
git push




Check YAML header for syntax errors
Look for unmatched brackets or quotes
Run chunks one-by-one to find the error





Close unused projects
Increase RAM: Project Settings → Resources → RAM
Clear old outputs: delete _freeze/ folder




# Regenerate SSH key
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your.email@unc.edu"
# Add to GitHub: Settings → SSH Keys → New






Slack #hpm883-help — Quick questions, classmates can help
Office Hours — See course schedule
GitHub Issues — For persistent technical problems







NoteLab 0



Complete Lab 0 during Week 1 to verify your environment is correctly configured. If you encounter issues, bring them to office hours.

title: Student Setup Guide
text:
This guide walks you through setting up your computing environment for HPM 883. Complete these steps before the first class or during the first week.






ImportantRequired Software



You need to install:

R (version 4.3 or higher)
Positron (recommended) or RStudio
Git and a GitHub account
Posit Cloud account ($5/month)
Quarto (usually bundled with Positron/RStudio)








Open PowerShell and run:
winget install --id R-project.R
Or download from CRAN.



Open Terminal and run:
brew install --cask r
Or download from CRAN.



Open a terminal and type:
R --version
You should see R version 4.3.0 or higher.





Positron is Posit’s new IDE with built-in AI assistance. It’s free and actively developed.



Go to positron.posit.co
Download the installer for your operating system
Run the installer







Feature
Positron
RStudio




Built-in AI assistant
✓ Yes
No


VS Code extensions
✓ 1000s
Limited


Active development
✓ Very active
Maintenance only


Python support
First-class
Secondary


Price
Free
Free






If you prefer RStudio, download from posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop.







Windows:
winget install Git.Git
macOS:
brew install git



Open a terminal and run (use your actual name and email):
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your.email@unc.edu"




Go to github.com
Sign up with your UNC email (you get free Pro features as a student)
Verify your email address




Generate an SSH key (recommended):
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your.email@unc.edu"
Press Enter to accept defaults. Then add to GitHub:

Copy your public key: cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub
Go to GitHub → Settings → SSH and GPG keys → New SSH key
Paste and save




ssh -T git@github.com
You should see: “Hi username! You’ve successfully authenticated…”





Posit Cloud provides a browser-based R environment for in-class exercises.



Go to posit.cloud
Sign up with your UNC email
Subscribe to the Student plan ($5/month)







NoteCourse Requirement



The $5/month Posit Cloud subscription is a required course cost. This gives you:

75 project hours/month (plenty for class)
4 GB RAM per project
Up to 20 projects






After enrollment, you’ll receive a link to join the HPM 883 course workspace. This gives you access to pre-configured projects for in-class exercises.





Quarto is the publishing system we use for labs and the capstone project.


Positron and recent RStudio versions include Quarto. Check:
quarto --version
If not found, download from quarto.org/docs/get-started.





Once the semester starts, you’ll receive GitHub Classroom assignment links.



Click the assignment link (e.g., https://classroom.github.com/a/xyz123)
Authorize GitHub Classroom (first time only)
Accept the assignment → This creates your personal repository
Clone to your computer:

git clone git@github.com:unc-hpm-quant/lab-0-yourusername.git

Open the .Rproj file in Positron/RStudio




When you first open a project, restore packages:
renv::restore()
This installs all required packages in the correct versions.








Log into Posit Cloud
Open the class project
Follow along with the instructor
No submission needed (formative)





Accept GitHub Classroom assignment
Clone to local machine
Open in Positron/RStudio
Run renv::restore() (first time)
Complete the assignment
Render to HTML
Commit and push to GitHub
Verify submission on GitHub




Same as labs, but uses the extended capstone template with:

targets pipeline
Pre-analysis plan
Multi-file structure















Problem
Solution




renv::restore() fails
Delete renv/library/, restart R, try again


Package not found
Run renv::install("package_name")


Git push rejected
Run git pull first, then push


Quarto render fails
Check YAML header syntax


GitHub auth fails
Regenerate SSH key, re-add to GitHub


Posit Cloud slow
Increase project RAM in settings







Slack #hpm883-help — Post questions, classmates can help
Office Hours — See course schedule
GitHub Issues — For persistent technical problems






Before the first class, verify:

R installed (version 4.3+)
Positron or RStudio installed
Git installed and configured
GitHub account created
SSH key added to GitHub
Posit Cloud account with Student plan
Quarto installed

Complete Lab 0 during Week 1 to verify everything works together.

R for Data Science — Learn R basics
Quarto Documentation — Quarto reference
Positron Documentation — IDE guide

title: Semester Project Description
text:
With the semester project, you’ll dive into the full experimental research lifecycle and apply the tools and techniques you’re learning in this course. Working in your assigned group, you’ll design an experiment to answer a meaningful research question of your choosing, develop a pre-analysis plan, and analyze data (we’ll simulate the data given time constraints). By the end of the semester, you’ll have a manuscript and replication package that showcase your ability to design, execute, and report on a rigorous experimental research project. This is your opportunity to apply what we learn in class to a topic of interest.






The Pre-Analysis Plan (PAP) ensures your experiment is well-conceived, transparent, and analytically rigorous. This document lays out your research design and specifies how you will analyze the data.



Introduction and Background: Explain your research question and its significance.

Hypotheses: Clearly state primary and secondary hypotheses.

Experimental Design:

Type of experiment (e.g., lab, online A/B test, field).

Random assignment procedure.

Treatment and control conditions.

Participant details (e.g., recruitment, sample size, inclusion criteria).


Key Outcomes: Define primary and secondary outcomes and describe how they will be measured.

Analytical Strategy:

Specify statistical methods and models.

Incorporate analysis related to compliance or heterogeneous treatment effects.

Use a machine learning approach (e.g., predicting treatment heterogeneity or analyzing secondary outcomes).

Address how you will handle multiple hypotheses testing, if applicable.


Limitations: Discuss potential weaknesses and their impact on findings.





Clarity and Completeness (40%)

Rigor of Design and Analysis (40%)

Feasibility and Practicality (20%)





Pre-Analysis Plan Template
For guidance on pre-analysis plans: World Bank DIME Wiki
For examples of pre-analysis plans: AEA RCT Registry






This deliverable includes a journal-style manuscript and a replication package to showcase your research findings and ensure reproducibility.



Final Manuscript: (10–15 pages)

Abstract: Concise summary of your study and findings.
Introduction: Background and motivation for your research.
Methods: Detailed description of your experimental design, treatments, and analytical approach.
Results: Clear presentation of findings, including tables and figures.
Discussion: Interpretation, limitations, and implications for future research or policy.
References: Properly formatted citations.

Replication Package:

Simulated Data: Dataset formatted for analysis.
Code: Well-documented scripts (R or Python recommended) for data cleaning and analysis, incorporating machine learning where appropriate.
README File: Detailed instructions for replicating your analysis.






Manuscript:

Writing Quality and Organization (20%)
Clarity and Depth of Analysis (30%)

Replication Package:

Reproducibility (30%)
Completeness and Documentation (20%)









Now - April 9: Work with team on pre-analysis plan.
April 9: Submit Pre-Analysis Plan for feedback.
April 9 - April 28: Simulate and analyze data; draft your final deliverable.
April 28: Submit Final Manuscript and Replication Package.






Pre-Analysis Plan: 50%
Final Manuscript and Replication Package: 50%

A global research center based at MIT’s Economics Department that works to reduce poverty through rigorous scientific evidence and policy implementation

JPAL maintains an excellent site with resources for randomized evaluations and more

Stanford Social Impact Lab

EconDL is a comprehensive resource detailing applications of Deep Learning in Economics. This is a companion website to the paper Deep Learning for Economists and aims to be a go-to resource for economists and other social scientists for applying tools provided by deep learning in their research.

title: Useful Reference Materials
text:
Data

Stanford GSB Social Impact Lab Experiment Data
MIMIC-IV (Medical Information Mart for Intensive Care IV)
MIMIC-IV is an updated version of the MIMIC database, containing comprehensive de-identified electronic health records from patients admitted to Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston, MA from 2008 to 2019. This freely accessible dataset includes data from over 257,000 distinct patients, yielding approximately 524,000 admission records.
Key Features and Structure
MIMIC-IV adopts a modular approach to data organization, highlighting data provenance and facilitating both individual and combined use of different data sources. The database is organized into three main modules:

hosp: Contains hospital-wide data including admission/discharge/transfer records, laboratory values, microbiology cultures, medication orders, and administrative data from billing practices
icu: Comprises data documented at the ICU bedside, including intravenous infusions, patient outputs, charted observations, and documentation of ongoing procedures
note: Contains discharge summaries, radiology reports, and other clinical notes in free-text format
Detailed Description
MIMIC Code Repository

Papers With Code
Papers with Code is a free and open resource platform dedicated to making machine learning research more accessible by connecting research papers with their code implementations.

title: Session 0.1: Course Overview & Causal Inference Foundations
text:
Welcome to HPM 883
Advanced Quantitative Methods for Health Policy and Management
Spring 2026

Welcome students. This is the third course in the quantitative methods sequence. We’re going to explore cutting-edge methods at the intersection of causal inference and machine learning.

title: Session 0.1: Course Overview & Causal Inference Foundations
text:
Course Philosophy


What This Course Is

Applied focus: Real health policy problems
Modern methods: Causal ML, not just regression
Reproducible research: Code that others can run
AI-assisted analysis: Learning to work with AI tools


What This Course Is Not

A statistics refresher (prerequisite: HPM 881-882)
Pure machine learning for prediction
Theory without application
AI doing your thinking for you



Set expectations early. This is an advanced course that builds on prior quantitative training. We’ll use modern methods but always with a focus on causal questions that matter for health policy.

title: Session 0.1: Course Overview & Causal Inference Foundations
text:
The Central Question

When does a health intervention cause an outcome to change?


This is fundamentally different from:

“Are intervention and outcome associated?”
“Can we predict outcomes from interventions?”







Key Insight


Prediction ≠ Causation. A model that predicts well may tell us nothing about what happens when we intervene.

title: Session 0.1: Course Overview & Causal Inference Foundations
text:
The Three-Layer Causal Inference Stack

flowchart TB
    subgraph Layer3["Layer 3: DECISION"]
        D1["What should we do?"]
        D2["Policy learning"]
        D3["Optimal treatment rules"]
    end

    subgraph Layer2["Layer 2: ESTIMATION"]
        E1["How do we estimate effects?"]
        E2["Double ML, Causal Forests"]
        E3["Doubly-robust methods"]
    end

    subgraph Layer1["Layer 1: IDENTIFICATION"]
        I1["What assumptions justify causal claims?"]
        I2["RCTs, Natural experiments"]
        I3["DAGs, Potential outcomes"]
    end

    Layer1 --> Layer2
    Layer2 --> Layer3

    style Layer1 fill:#e6f3ff
    style Layer2 fill:#fff2e6
    style Layer3 fill:#e6ffe6




flowchart TB
    subgraph Layer3["Layer 3: DECISION"]
        D1["What should we do?"]
        D2["Policy learning"]
        D3["Optimal treatment rules"]
    end

    subgraph Layer2["Layer 2: ESTIMATION"]
        E1["How do we estimate effects?"]
        E2["Double ML, Causal Forests"]
        E3["Doubly-robust methods"]
    end

    subgraph Layer1["Layer 1: IDENTIFICATION"]
        I1["What assumptions justify causal claims?"]
        I2["RCTs, Natural experiments"]
        I3["DAGs, Potential outcomes"]
    end

    Layer1 --> Layer2
    Layer2 --> Layer3

    style Layer1 fill:#e6f3ff
    style Layer2 fill:#fff2e6
    style Layer3 fill:#e6ffe6







This three-layer stack is the organizing framework for the entire course. Every method we learn fits somewhere in this stack. Identification comes first—you must know what you’re estimating before worrying about how to estimate it.

title: Session 0.1: Course Overview & Causal Inference Foundations
text:
Layer 1: Identification
The Question: Under what assumptions can we interpret an estimate as causal?


Tools

Potential outcomes framework
Directed Acyclic Graphs (DAGs)
Identification strategies


Course Coverage

Unit 0: Foundations
Unit 1: Experimental design
Unit 5-6: Observational strategies








Identification First


No amount of sophisticated estimation can rescue a study with flawed identification.

title: Session 0.1: Course Overview & Causal Inference Foundations
text:
Layer 2: Estimation
The Question: Given valid identification, how do we estimate effects efficiently?


Tools

Double/Debiased ML
Doubly-robust estimation
Causal forests
Influence functions


Course Coverage

Unit 2: DR & DML
Unit 3: Heterogeneous effects
Units 5-6: Advanced methods








Modern Estimation


ML methods excel at high-dimensional nuisance estimation while preserving valid inference on causal parameters.

title: Session 0.1: Course Overview & Causal Inference Foundations
text:
Layer 3: Decision
The Question: Given estimated effects, what action should we take?


Tools

Policy learning
Treatment rules
Off-policy evaluation


Course Coverage

Unit 4: Policy learning
Unit 8: Capstone projects








Decision Under Uncertainty


Optimal decisions depend not just on average effects, but on heterogeneity and constraints.

title: Session 0.1: Course Overview & Causal Inference Foundations
text:
Why “AI in the Loop”?


Human-Driven, AI-Assisted

You specify the causal question
You choose the identification strategy
AI assists with implementation
You evaluate and interpret results
You make the decision

This is “AI in the Loop” — not “Human in the Loop”

Why It Matters

AI can’t choose your research question
AI can hallucinate methods
AI doesn’t know your context
AI can’t defend your work
You are responsible



This distinction is crucial. Many people talk about “human in the loop” for AI systems. In research, we flip this: the human drives the process, AI assists. You maintain control and responsibility.

title: Session 0.1: Course Overview & Causal Inference Foundations
section: AI in Causal Analysis: Do’s and Don’ts
text:
AI in Causal Analysis: Do’s and Don’ts


✅ Good Uses of AI

Code implementation
Debugging syntax errors
Explaining methods
Generating simulations
Formatting output


❌ Risky Uses of AI

Choosing identification strategy
Interpreting results for you
Making causal claims
Selecting variables
“Just run an analysis”








Course Policy


You may use AI tools, but you are responsible for all submitted work. You must understand and be able to explain every line of code and every claim.

title: Session 0.1: Course Overview & Causal Inference Foundations
text:
Potential Outcomes Framework
The Fundamental Setup
For each unit \(i\):

\(Y_i(1)\): Outcome if unit receives treatment
\(Y_i(0)\): Outcome if unit receives control
\(D_i\): Treatment indicator (1 = treated, 0 = control)

. . .
The Individual Treatment Effect
\[\tau_i = Y_i(1) - Y_i(0)\]
The causal effect for unit \(i\) is the difference between what would happen under treatment versus control.

This notation will be used throughout the course. Get comfortable with it. Y(1) is the potential outcome under treatment, Y(0) under control. These are counterfactual outcomes—we can only ever observe one for each unit.

title: Session 0.1: Course Overview & Causal Inference Foundations
section: The Fundamental Problem of Causal Inference
text:
The Fundamental Problem of Causal Inference






The Problem


We can never observe both \(Y_i(1)\) and \(Y_i(0)\) for the same unit.






Unit
\(Y_i(1)\)
\(Y_i(0)\)
\(\tau_i\)




1
8
?
?


2
?
5
?


3
7
?
?


4
?
6
?




Solution: Randomization allows us to estimate average effects by comparing groups.

title: Session 0.1: Course Overview & Causal Inference Foundations
text:
Average Treatment Effect (ATE)
Definition
\[\text{ATE} = E[Y(1) - Y(0)] = E[Y(1)] - E[Y(0)]\]
The average causal effect across the population.
. . .
Under Random Assignment
\[\text{ATE} = E[Y | D=1] - E[Y | D=0]\]
Why? Because randomization ensures:
\[E[Y(1) | D=1] = E[Y(1)] \quad \text{and} \quad E[Y(0) | D=0] = E[Y(0)]\]

This is the magic of randomization. It breaks the link between treatment assignment and potential outcomes, allowing us to estimate average causal effects by comparing means.

title: Session 0.1: Course Overview & Causal Inference Foundations
text:
Beyond Average Effects: CATE
Conditional Average Treatment Effect
\[\text{CATE}(x) = E[Y(1) - Y(0) | X = x]\]
The average effect for units with characteristics \(X = x\).
. . .
Why It Matters for Health Policy

Personalized medicine: Who benefits most from treatment?
Resource allocation: Where should we target interventions?
Equity: Do effects differ across populations?







Course Focus


Units 3-4 focus on estimating heterogeneous effects using causal forests and policy learning.

title: Session 0.1: Course Overview & Causal Inference Foundations
text:
Introduction to Causal Graphs (DAGs)
Directed Acyclic Graphs
Visual representations of causal relationships:

flowchart LR
    X["Confounder<br/>X"] --> D["Treatment<br/>D"]
    X --> Y["Outcome<br/>Y"]
    D --> Y

    style X fill:#ffcccc
    style D fill:#cce5ff
    style Y fill:#ccffcc




flowchart LR
    X["Confounder<br/>X"] --> D["Treatment<br/>D"]
    X --> Y["Outcome<br/>Y"]
    D --> Y

    style X fill:#ffcccc
    style D fill:#cce5ff
    style Y fill:#ccffcc







Nodes: Variables
Arrows: Direct causal effects
Paths: Chains of causal relationships


DAGs are powerful tools for reasoning about identification. We’ll use them throughout the course to think about what we need to control for and what we should not control for.

Why DAGs Matter
Confounding

flowchart LR

    Access --> Health

    style SES fill:#ffcccc

    Access --> Health

    style SES fill:#ffcccc






SES confounds the relationship between access and health.
. . .
Without adjustment: Association ≠ Causation
With adjustment for SES: We can isolate the causal effect of access

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
Today’s Agenda

Deep dive into potential outcomes
Counterfactual reasoning
Directed Acyclic Graphs (DAGs)
d-Separation and identification
Confounding vs. selection bias


This is conceptual and mathematical. Heavy on notation but essential for everything that follows.

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
section: The Fundamental Problem of Causal Inference
text:
The Fundamental Problem of Causal Inference
Patient i receives treatment




Treated (Z=1)
Control (Z=0)




Observed
\(Y_i(1)\)
?


Counterfactual
?
\(Y_i(0)\)




The Problem
We can never observe both \(Y_i(1)\) and \(Y_i(0)\) for the same unit.
Individual treatment effect \(\tau_i = Y_i(1) - Y_i(0)\) is unobservable.

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
Potential Outcomes Notation
Definition
For each unit \(i\):

\(Y_i(1)\) = outcome if treated (potential outcome under treatment)
\(Y_i(0)\) = outcome if control (potential outcome under control)
\(Z_i\) = treatment indicator (1 = treated, 0 = control)


Observed Outcome
\[Y_i = Z_i \cdot Y_i(1) + (1 - Z_i) \cdot Y_i(0)\]
We only see one potential outcome for each unit.

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
Treatment Effects
Individual Treatment Effect (ITE)
\[\tau_i = Y_i(1) - Y_i(0)\]
Unobservable — would need to see same unit in both states

Average Treatment Effect (ATE)
\[\tau_{ATE} = E[Y_i(1) - Y_i(0)] = E[Y_i(1)] - E[Y_i(0)]\]
Observable — with the right design


Other Estimands

ATT: \(E[Y(1) - Y(0) | Z = 1]\)
ATU: \(E[Y(1) - Y(0) | Z = 0]\)
CATE: \(E[Y(1) - Y(0) | X = x]\)

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
The Selection Problem
Naive Comparison
\[\hat{\tau}_{naive} = E[Y | Z=1] - E[Y | Z=0]\]

Decomposition
\[
\begin{aligned}
E[Y | Z=1] - E[Y | Z=0] &= \underbrace{E[Y(1) | Z=1] - E[Y(0) | Z=1]}_{\text{ATT}} \\
&+ \underbrace{E[Y(0) | Z=1] - E[Y(0) | Z=0]}_{\text{Selection Bias}}
\end{aligned}
\]







Key Insight


Naive comparison = Treatment effect + Selection bias
Without randomization, we can’t separate them.

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
Randomization Solves Selection
Under Randomization
\[Z \perp\!\!\!\perp \{Y(0), Y(1)\}\]
Treatment is independent of potential outcomes.

Consequence
\[
\begin{aligned}
E[Y(0) | Z=1] &= E[Y(0) | Z=0] = E[Y(0)] \\
E[Y(1) | Z=1] &= E[Y(1) | Z=0] = E[Y(1)]
\end{aligned}
\]
Selection bias = 0!

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
The Identification Assumption
Unconfoundedness (Ignorability)
\[\{Y(0), Y(1)\} \perp\!\!\!\perp Z | X\]
Given covariates \(X\), treatment is as-if random.

What This Means

All confounders are measured
No unmeasured common causes
Allows causal interpretation in observational data
Strong and untestable assumption

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
Stability Assumption (SUTVA)
Stable Unit Treatment Value Assumption
Two components:

No interference: \(Y_i\) depends only on \(Z_i\), not \(Z_j\) for \(j \neq i\)
No hidden versions: Treatment is well-defined


When SUTVA Fails

Interference: Vaccines (herd immunity)
Hidden versions: “Job training” means many things
Spillovers: Treated patients share rooms with controls

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
Directed Acyclic Graphs (DAGs)
A Visual Language for Causal Assumptions

flowchart LR
    Z["Treatment<br>(Z)"] --> Y["Outcome<br>(Y)"]




flowchart LR
    Z["Treatment<br>(Z)"] --> Y["Outcome<br>(Y)"]






Notation: - Nodes = Variables - Arrows = Direct causal effects - Missing arrows = No direct effect

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
DAG Elements
Confounding

flowchart TB
    X["Confounder<br>(X)"] --> Z["Treatment<br>(Z)"]
    X --> Y["Outcome<br>(Y)"]
    Z --> Y




flowchart TB
    X["Confounder<br>(X)"] --> Z["Treatment<br>(Z)"]
    X --> Y["Outcome<br>(Y)"]
    Z --> Y






\(X\) creates spurious association between \(Z\) and \(Y\)

Solution
Adjust for \(X\) (conditioning, regression, matching, weighting)

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
Mediator

flowchart LR
    Z["Treatment<br>(Z)"] --> M["Mediator<br>(M)"]
    M --> Y["Outcome<br>(Y)"]




flowchart LR
    Z["Treatment<br>(Z)"] --> M["Mediator<br>(M)"]
    M --> Y["Outcome<br>(Y)"]






\(M\) is on the causal pathway from \(Z\) to \(Y\)






Do NOT Adjust for Mediators


Adjusting for \(M\) blocks the causal effect you’re trying to estimate!

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
Collider

flowchart TB
    Z["Treatment<br>(Z)"] --> C["Collider<br>(C)"]
    Y["Outcome<br>(Y)"] --> C




flowchart TB
    Z["Treatment<br>(Z)"] --> C["Collider<br>(C)"]
    Y["Outcome<br>(Y)"] --> C






\(C\) is caused by both \(Z\) and \(Y\)

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
Collider Bias
Adjusting for \(C\) creates spurious association between \(Z\) and \(Y\)!
Classic mistake in observational studies.

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
d-Separation
Rules for Reading DAGs
A path is blocked if it contains:

A chain \(A \rightarrow B \rightarrow C\) and we condition on \(B\)
A fork \(A \leftarrow B \rightarrow C\) and we condition on \(B\)
A collider \(A \rightarrow B \leftarrow C\) and we don’t condition on \(B\)


Two Variables are d-Separated
If all paths between them are blocked.
d-Separated variables are conditionally independent.

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
Example: Complex DAG

flowchart TB
    U["Unobserved<br>Confounder"] --> Z["Treatment"]
    U --> Y["Outcome"]
    Z --> M["Mediator"]
    Z --> Y
    M --> Y
    X["Observed<br>Covariate"] --> Z
    X --> Y




flowchart TB
    U["Unobserved<br>Confounder"] --> Z["Treatment"]
    U --> Y["Outcome"]
    Z --> M["Mediator"]
    Z --> Y
    M --> Y
    X["Observed<br>Covariate"] --> Z
    X --> Y







Analysis

Confounding path: \(Z \leftarrow U \rightarrow Y\) (blocked by conditioning on \(U\), but \(U\) unobserved!)
Adjustment set: Must include \(X\); cannot adjust for unobserved \(U\)
Problem: Causal effect not identified without more assumptions

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
Confounding vs. Selection Bias
Confounding

flowchart TB
    X --> Z
    X --> Y
    Z --> Y




flowchart TB
    X --> Z
    X --> Y
    Z --> Y






A common cause creates spurious association

Selection Bias (Collider)

flowchart TB
    Z --> S["Selection"]
    Y --> S
    Z --> Y




flowchart TB
    Z --> S["Selection"]
    Y --> S
    Z --> Y






Conditioning on a common effect creates spurious association

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
Example: Selection Bias
“Hospital patients who receive treatment X have worse outcomes”

flowchart TB
    D["Disease<br>Severity"] --> H["Hospital<br>Admission"]
    D --> Y["Outcome"]
    T["Treatment"] --> H
    T --> Y




flowchart TB
    D["Disease<br>Severity"] --> H["Hospital<br>Admission"]
    D --> Y["Outcome"]
    T["Treatment"] --> H
    T --> Y







The Problem
By studying only hospital patients, we condition on admission (a collider).
This creates spurious negative association between treatment and outcomes.

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
Structural Causal Models (SCMs)
Beyond DAGs: The Math
An SCM specifies:

Endogenous variables: \(V = \{Y, Z, X, ...\}\)
Exogenous variables: \(U = \{U_Y, U_Z, ...\}\)
Structural equations: \(Y = f_Y(pa(Y), U_Y)\)


Example
\[
\begin{aligned}
X &= U_X \\
Z &= g(X) + U_Z \\
Y &= \beta Z + \gamma X + U_Y
\end{aligned}
\]

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
Interventions in SCMs
The do() Operator
\(P(Y | do(Z=1))\) ≠ \(P(Y | Z=1)\)
do(Z=1): Set \(Z=1\) by intervention, breaking all arrows into \(Z\)
Z=1: Observe that \(Z=1\), preserving all relationships

Graphically

flowchart TB
    X -.-> Z
    X --> Y
    Z --> Y

    style Z fill:#f9f,stroke:#333




flowchart TB
    X -.-> Z
    X --> Y
    Z --> Y

    style Z fill:#f9f,stroke:#333






\(do(Z=1)\) removes all arrows into \(Z\)

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
The Adjustment Formula
Backdoor Criterion
If \(X\) blocks all backdoor paths from \(Z\) to \(Y\):
\[P(Y | do(Z)) = \sum_x P(Y | Z, X=x) P(X=x)\]

In Practice

Draw DAG
Find adjustment set (backdoor criterion)
Condition on adjustment set
Estimate effect (regression, matching, weighting)

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
Code Example: Simulating Confounding

library(tidyverse)
set.seed(883)

n <- 1000

# Generate data with confounding
df <- tibble(
  X = rnorm(n),                    # Confounder
  Z = rbinom(n, 1, plogis(0.5*X)), # Treatment depends on X
  Y0 = 2 + 1*X + rnorm(n),         # Potential outcome under control
  Y1 = Y0 + 0.5,                   # True effect = 0.5
  Y = ifelse(Z == 1, Y1, Y0)       # Observed outcome
)

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
Naive vs. Adjusted Estimate

library(estimatr)

# Naive estimate (biased)
naive <- lm_robust(Y ~ Z, data = df)

# Adjusted estimate (unbiased)
adjusted <- lm_robust(Y ~ Z + X, data = df)

tribble(
  ~Estimator, ~Estimate, ~SE, ~True,
  "Naive", coef(naive)["Z"], naive$std.error["Z"], 0.5,
  "Adjusted", coef(adjusted)["Z"], adjusted$std.error["Z"], 0.5
)


Lesson: Adjusting for confounders removes bias!

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
Visualizing Confounding

ggplot(df, aes(x = X, y = Y, color = factor(Z))) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) +
  labs(title = "Confounding: Treated units have higher X",
       color = "Treatment") +
  theme_minimal()

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
DAG Tools in R
Using ggdag

library(ggdag)

dag <- dagify(
  Y ~ Z + X,
  Z ~ X,
  exposure = "Z",
  outcome = "Y"
)

ggdag_adjustment_set(dag) + theme_dag()

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
Key Assumptions Summary



Assumption
Meaning
Testable?




SUTVA
No interference, well-defined treatment
Partially


Unconfoundedness
No unmeasured confounders
No


Positivity
All units have chance of treatment
Yes


Consistency
Potential outcome = observed if treated
No









Critical Insight


Causal inference requires assumptions. These assumptions are often untestable. Be explicit about what you’re assuming.

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
Practical Guidelines
When Drawing DAGs

Include all common causes you can think of
Ask domain experts
Be explicit about what’s unobserved
Don’t include mediators unless studying mechanisms
Check for colliders before conditioning

When Making Assumptions

State them clearly
Justify them substantively
Test robustness to violations
Be honest about limitations

title: Session 0.3: Potential Outcomes & Structural Causal Models
text:
Key Takeaways

Potential outcomes define causal effects as contrasts between possible worlds
Selection bias arises when treatment is related to outcomes
DAGs visualize causal assumptions and guide identification
d-Separation tells us what we must adjust for (and what we must not!)
SCMs formalize interventions with the do() operator

title: Session 0.2: Reproducible Research & Computing Setup

Why Reproducibility Matters


The Reproducibility Crisis

70%+ of researchers have failed to reproduce another’s work
50%+ have failed to reproduce their own work
Retractions increasing exponentially


Our Solution

Version control (Git)
Package management (renv)
Pipeline automation (targets)
Literate programming (Quarto)








Course Requirement


All submitted work must be reproducible. If we can’t run your code, we can’t grade it.

title: Session 0.2: Reproducible Research & Computing Setup
text:
Introduction to DeclareDesign
A Grammar for Research Design
DeclareDesign provides a unified framework:

Model (M): Data generating process
Inquiry (I): What we want to learn
Data Strategy (D): How we collect data
Answer Strategy (A): How we estimate

design <- declare_model(...) +
          declare_inquiry(...) +
          declare_sampling(...) +
          declare_assignment(...) +
          declare_estimator(...)

title: Session 0.2: Reproducible Research & Computing Setup
text:
The MIDA Framework

flowchart LR
    M["Model<br>(DGP)"] --> I["Inquiry<br>(Estimand)"]
    I --> D["Data Strategy<br>(Sampling, Assignment)"]
    D --> A["Answer Strategy<br>(Estimator)"]
    A --> |"Diagnosis"| M




flowchart LR
    M["Model<br>(DGP)"] --> I["Inquiry<br>(Estimand)"]
    I --> D["Data Strategy<br>(Sampling, Assignment)"]
    D --> A["Answer Strategy<br>(Estimator)"]
    A --> |"Diagnosis"| M







Key Insight
Design declaration before data collection forces clear thinking about:

What we’re trying to learn (estimand)
What assumptions we’re making (model)
How we’ll analyze the data (estimator)

title: Session 0.2: Reproducible Research & Computing Setup
text:
Example: Simple RCT

library(DeclareDesign)
library(tidyverse)

# Declare the design
simple_rct <- declare_model(
  N = 100,
  U = rnorm(N),
  potential_outcomes(Y ~ 0.5 * Z + U)
) +
declare_inquiry(ATE = mean(Y_Z_1 - Y_Z_0)) +
declare_assignment(Z = complete_ra(N)) +
declare_measurement(Y = reveal_outcomes(Y ~ Z)) +
declare_estimator(Y ~ Z, .method = lm_robust)

title: Session 0.2: Reproducible Research & Computing Setup
text:
Running the Design

# Run once
run_design(simple_rct) |>
  select(inquiry, estimand, estimate, std.error) |>
  head(1)


What just happened?

Generated 100 units with potential outcomes
Randomly assigned to treatment
Revealed observed outcomes
Estimated ATE with robust SEs

title: Session 0.2: Reproducible Research & Computing Setup
Session 0.2: Reproducible Research & Computing Setup
text:
Interpretation



Metric
Value
Target




Bias
~0
Near 0


RMSE
~0.20
Low


Power
~0.60
≥ 0.80


Coverage
~0.95
0.95




Problem: Underpowered!
With N=100 and true effect of 0.5, we only have ~60% power.
Solutions: - Increase sample size - Block on predictive covariates - Use CUPED/regression adjustment

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Course Description
HPM 883 is an advanced graduate-level course designed to equip PhD students in Health Policy and Management with sophisticated quantitative research skills. This course is the third installment in the quantitative methods sequence, building on foundations from HPM 881 and HPM 882.
The course integrates experimental design principles with modern causal machine learning methods, following a three-layer framework: Identification → Estimation → Decision.
Focus Areas:

Experimental design and randomization inference
Double/Debiased Machine Learning (DML)
Heterogeneous treatment effects and causal forests
Policy learning and optimal treatment rules
Modern causal inference methods (DiD, synthetic controls)

Course Format: This is a hybrid course combining in-person lectures (theory and discussion) with remote Zoom sessions (coding labs and implementation).

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Learning Objectives
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:








#
Learning Objective
Assessment Evidence




1
Design randomized experiments with appropriate power analysis, randomization strategies, and variance reduction techniques
Design Memo 1, PS 1, Capstone Project


2
Implement Double/Debiased Machine Learning and doubly-robust estimators for causal inference
PS 2, Design Memo 2, Capstone Project


3
Estimate heterogeneous treatment effects using causal forests and meta-learners
PS 3, Capstone Project


4
Evaluate Conditional Average Treatment Effect (CATE) estimates using calibration diagnostics
PS 3, Capstone Project


5
Learn optimal treatment policies from observational data using policy trees
PS 4, Capstone Project


6
Apply modern difference-in-differences and synthetic control methods
PS 5, Capstone Project


7
Diagnose common problems including overlap violations, confounding, and model misspecification
PS 2-5, Design Memos, Capstone Project


8
Produce reproducible research using modern workflow tools (renv, targets, Quarto)
PS 0, All Problem Sets, Capstone Project

Grading Scale
Final course grades follow the UNC Graduate School grading scale:

H — High Pass (93-100): Clear excellence
P — Pass (80-92): Entirely satisfactory graduate work
L — Low Pass (70-79): Inadequate graduate work
F — Fail (0-69)

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Policies

AI Use Policy
The use of AI tools (such as ChatGPT, GitHub Copilot, or Claude) is permitted and encouraged for:

Debugging code
Understanding error messages
Learning syntax and package functions
Generating code snippets for adaptation

However, you are responsible for all code you submit — AI-generated code must be understood, tested, and verified. Conceptual understanding cannot be outsourced.


Late Work

Late submissions: -10% per 24 hours
After 48 hours: No credit without prior arrangement
Extensions may be granted for documented circumstances if requested before the deadline








NoteComplete Details



For full course policies, institutional requirements, and detailed schedule, please download the complete syllabus (PDF).
